Looks at the ways the romantic sublime moves freely between aesthetics, philosophy, morality, and politics, challenging the rationalism of the Enlightenment. We will also give special attention to manners as a crucial cultural battleground between aristocratic status and bourgeois striving: not just the details of eating, dress, gesture, and speech, in other words, but also how those details tell the story of modern subjectivity. course.course_name: New York City in American Literature
course.course_description: New York is the most storied city in American literature. From Melville's Bartleby, the Scrivener to Morrison's Jazz, from Whitman's "Crossing Brooklyn Ferry" and Emma Lazarus' "City Visions" to Hart Crane's "The Bridge" and Frank O'Hara's "The Day Lady Died," countless authors have sought to capture the special energy and allure--as well as the growing pains, existential challenges, and social conflicts--of our unique metropolis. This course takes up a wide variety of works, both prose fiction and poetry, from distinctive epochs of City history. To appreciate the emergence of New York as both a center of national culture and a world capital vying with the likes London and Paris--a new "hub of the universe," to appropriate O. W. Holmes's phrase--we will study Howells's A Hazard of New Fortunes, Wharton's The House of Mirth, Abraham Cahan's Yekl: A Tale of the New York Ghetto, James's "The Jolly Corner," Dreiser's Sister Carrie, and Crane's Maggie: A Girl of the Streets. The rich themes of urban experience engaged by these works--money and class dynamics, immigration and ethnic diversity, gender politics, architectural and material culture, the trials and triumphs of self-identity--resurface in a new guise, and with new intensity, in the Jazz Age and Harlem Renaissance. Representative works include Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby, Anzia Yezierska's Bread Givers, poetry by Claude McKay, Countee Cullen, and Langston Hughes, Zora Neale Hurston's "Story in Harlem Slang," and Willa Cather's surprising tale of Greenwich Village, "Coming, Aphrodite!" Our readings conclude with works drawn from the broad middle of the 20th century, which register the difficult legacies of American history in domestic social life, as well as the new meanings of "America" in an increasingly global setting: Bernard Malamud's "The Cost of Living," I. B. Singer's "The Cafeteria," James Baldwin's "Sonny's Blues," and Ralph Ellison's Invisible Man will be among the centerpieces. We also delve into verse of this period that variously celebrates, interrogates, or ruminates on the colorful, exuberant, and often troubling complexity of the City, covering such important artists as Marianne Moore, Elizabeth Bishop, Delmore Schwartz, George Oppen, Allen Ginsberg, James Merrill, and the New York School of poets. To enrich our sense of connections between this body of literature (and related art-forms like painting and photography) and the ever-shifting life of the City in general, we selectively consult the insights of social historians and documentary-makers such as Edwin Burrows, Thomas Bender, Ann Douglas, Ric Burns, and Kenneth Jackson. Circumstances permitting, we may attempt a voluntary "field trip" or two: Ellis Island, hot-spots of Harlem cultural history, the Whitney Museum of American Art, and/or the New-York Historical Society.

(Seminar). Irish Prose examines a tradition of writing in Ireland, beginning with The Tain and the uses of mythology in Irish saga writing, and including Edmund Spenser's ‘A View of the Present State of Ireland'. These two texts establish a tradition of the heroic and the anti-heroic in Ireland; they offer images of the country as a place ripe for epics or a culture ripe for destruction. The course then takes texts by Jonathan Swift, Maria Edgeworth, William Carleton, Bram Stoker, Oscar Wilde, Somerville and Ross, W.B. Yeats, John Millington Synge, James Joyce, Kate O'Brien and Samuel Beckett and traces an uneasy tradition of dramatising the broken, the alarming, the untrustworthy, the contested and the disappointed. The course looks at styles in Irish writing both invented and inherited. Most of the texts examined will be novels, but short stories, essays, travel writing and considerations of translation will also be part of the course. (Seminar). In Jack London's 1906 short story "The Apostate," an exposé of child labor, the narrator notes of a young millworker: "There had never been a time when he had not been in intimate relationship with machines." Drawing on novels, short stories, dramas, and essays by American and English writers from 1880 to WWII, this course seeks to understand what it means to become "intimate with machines." How did technology shape perception, consciousness, identity, and the understanding of the human in fin de siècle literature? What were the effects of new "writing machines," like the telegraph, phonograph, and typewriter, on traditional conceptions of authorship? How did technology intersect with class, race, and gender politics? What fears and fantasies did new inventions inspire? We will discuss how writers represented the cultural and social impact of technology and why they often felt compelled to invent new literary styles, forms, and movements--such as realism, aestheticism, and modernism--in order to do so. Texts by Herman Melville, Bram Stoker, Charlotte Perkins Gilman, Jack London, Sophie Treadwell, Thomas Alva Edison, Henry James, Virginia Woolf, and others. Application Instructions: E-mail Professor Biers (klb2134@columbia.edu) by noon on Tuesday, November 6th, with the subject heading, "Writing Machines seminar." (Seminar). We will pursue an introduction to Freud's basic works on the unconscious, dreams, the death drive, sexuality, and symptoms, by considering the narrative and argumentative dimensions of his case studies, his readings on literary and visual art, and his Interpretations of Dreams. Freud referred to his theory of drives as his own "poetry" and often approached the case study as a story-teller. Does the literary dimension of Freud's work contribute to the controversy over whether his claims are ultimately justifiable? To answer the question, we have first to pursue some others: Does he tell a story in order to make an argument, or are his arguments so many stories? At stake is whether there is an argumentative dimension to his narrative writing, or does he sidestep the need to make arguments by using figures and telling stories? Why are literary works so important his analysis, and how do they relate to the structure of dreams and fantasy? Finally, does Freud give us a way to think about the relationship between literature and philosophy? Can we say that psychoanalysis is one name for that relationship? Readings include The Relationship of Dreams, Beyond the Pleasure Principle, Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality, Totem and Taboo, Civilization and its Discontents. Case Studies include The Rat Man and Dora; essays include "Drives and their Vicissitudes" "The Unconscious" "The Uncanny" "The Economy of Masochism" and his reflections on Goethe and E.T.A. Hoffman, among others. Application Instructions: E-mail Professor Butler (jb3479@columbia.edu) by noon on Tuesday, November 6th, with the subject heading, "Freud seminar." In your message, include basic information: your name, school, major, year of study, and relevant courses taken, along with a brief statement about why you are interested in taking the course.

(Seminar). According to D.H. Lawrence, Thomas Hardy possessed "sensuous understanding... deeper than perhaps that of any other English novelist." In this seminar we will read the major novels of both authors, applying historical, biographical, psychoanalytic, feminist, Marxist, and other critical perspectives. We will pay particular attention to representations of class, sexuality, the body, spirituality, and landscape, as well as to each author´s unique philosophical views. Reading the two side by side will allow us to consider not only the nature of literary influence, but how Lawrence creates a new context for a deeper understanding of Hardy´s imagination. Moving back and forth across the 19th and 20th century divide, we will examine how modernism both breaks with and extends the tradition of the realist novel. Novels: The Mayor of Casterbridge, Tess of the D´Urbervilles, Jude the Obscure, Sons and Lovers, The Rainbow, and Lady Chatterley´s Lover. course.course_description: The intention of this course is to examine Chaucer's writings from the perspectives of the literary, social and political environments in which he lived and worked in fourteenth century England. How did Chaucer's literary productions engage in the adaptation and appropriation of established genres and narratives? How did they construct and perform social relations? How did they articulate institutional structures and cultural ideologies? Each of these questions will be considered with a view to critically opening up the dynamic and diverse universe that Chaucer and his English contemporaries depict. The course is open to all undergraduates though it will be of particular interest to students majoring in English and Comparative Literature who would like an introduction to the medieval period. No prior knowledge of medieval language or literature is necessary. Students will be learning to read Middle English as part of the course. The texts used have been chosen in order to give a beginner a good grasp of the period and to allow students with some knowledge to develop a sophisticated picture of the middle ages. The course will also be of interest to students of medieval studies.

course.course_name: Chaucer's Ventriloquism: Speaking in Other Voices
course.course_description: What are the literary structures that make the personalities in stories seem "alive" to us? In this course, we will seek alternatives to approaches to the literary text that center on "identities," "personalities," and "characters." Chaucer's works are especially well positioned to help us think through these questions. The Canterbury Tales, especially, is often read as a collection of stories voiced by individual characters with distinct personalities and identities. How do our understandings of these personalities change when we find out that these characters' speeches are actually re-voicings of other characters' speeches in other medieval texts? We will read the speeches of Chaucerian personalities alongside their "sources" and analogues - including Ovid, the Roman de la Rose, Machaut, and Gower. Throughout our investigation, we will incorporate the ideas of scholars and theorists who write about speaking multiply: Foucault, Bakhtin, Verducci, Lawton, Spearing, and more. The structure of Chaucer's ventriloquism undoes singular identities that speak in voices that are their own, and invites a consideration of what it might mean to speak multiply in other voices. The course is open to all undergraduates, and no prior experience in medieval languages and literatures is assumed. We will read Latin and French texts in translation, and learn to read Middle English as part of the course.

course.course_name: Introduction to Old English Language & Literature
course.course_description: (Lecture). This class is an introduction to the language and literature of England from around the 8th to the 11th centuries. Because this is predominantly a language class, we will spend much of our class time studying grammar as we learn to translate literary and non-literary texts. While this course provides a general historical framework for the period as it introduces you to the culture of Anglo-Saxon England, it will also take a close look at how each literary work contextualizes (or recontextualizes) relationships between human and divine, body and soul, individual and group, animal and human. We will be using Mitchell and Robinson's An Introduction to Old English, along with other supplements. We will be looking at recent scholarly work in the field and looking at different ways (theoretical, and other) of reading these medieval texts. Requirements: Students will be expected to do assignments for each meeting. The course will involve a mid-term, a final exam, and a final presentation on a Riddle which will also be turned in.

course.course_description: (Lecture). This course examines the literature of the turbulent final years of the sixteenth century in England, from the defeat of the Spanish Armada in 1588 to the death of Elizabeth I in 1603. It ranges over prose, drama, and verse of the period, often read in the context of other historical documents. Topics will include debates about the succession; the perceived threats from Spain and Roman Catholicism; economic hardships; immigration; the challenge posed by the earl of Essex; and concerns about Ireland and the Irish. Texts will include works by Edmund Spenser, Thomas Nashe, Christopher Marlowe, Thomas Dekker, William Shakespeare, and Francis Bacon, among others.

course.course_name: Devils, Tyrants, Murderers and Thieves: Misbehaving in Medieval Drama
course.course_description: A broad overview of the changes and continuities within early English drama from the twelfth through the early sixteenth century. This course focuses on the unexpected ways that misbehavior functions in medieval drama, which is often wrongly assumed to consist merely of thinly disguised sermons full of dry moral lessons. As much as medieval plays may aim to teach and guide behavior, they also seek to entertain. If they provide moral messages, they also feature swearing, sex, murder and mayhem; if they are full of saints, they are also full of sinners. The plays that we will read all, in different ways, deploy misbehavior and misrule within the communities they enact-from Punch-and-Judy-style domestic violence to false prophets with false miracles, from sheep theft to the abuse of education. Through closely examining both their textual and performance elements, we will explore the effects and implications of misbehavior in medieval drama, and, in particular, the roles that misbehavior has to play in community formation, rupture and repair. There are no prerequisites for this course. Instruction in the comprehension of Middle English will be provided.

course.course_name: Shrews, Gossips, Housewives & Whores: The Drama of Womens Work in Early Modern London
course.course_description: Shakespearean and non-Shakespearean drama in the context of recent feminist economic history that recovers the complexity, the variety, the dangers, and resourcefulness of women's participation in the hectic economy of early modern London.  Explores the relationship between gender, capitalist exchange, commodity culture, national identity, and performance.  This is a class about lady pawnbrokers, high-end whores, female con-artists, and formidable housewives.

course.course_name: The Renaissance in England: Shakespeare's Contemporaries
course.course_description: New York City offers a rare opportunity to view productions of plays not by Shakespeare a summer staple in towns across the country but by his contemporaries. Local companies have mounted acclaimed productions of plays by Renaissance dramatists such as Christopher Marlowe, Ben Jonson, and Thomas Middleton. Combining attendance at live performances with screenings of past ones, Shakespeares Rivals brings us closer to this dynamic period of theater history with it myriad theaters and playing companies, iconic actors and dramatists, and endless variety of plays. A guided tour at the Metropolitan museum of Art will introduce students to the material world of Renaissance England and a visit to a rare books library will offer insight into the life of plays in print. Ultimately, students will resurrect a forgotten non-Shakespearean Renaissance play, creating an apparatus (notes, summary and analysis), and staging a dramatic reading, bringing the dead back to life.

(Lecture). A survey of early British writing in its cultural contexts. The course begins with Anglo-Saxon poetry, traces the changes brought to Britain by the Norman Conquest, focuses on the literature of aristocratic courts in the later Middle Ages, and ends as Caxton sets up London's first printing press. We will read Anglo-Saxon works in translation and most Middle English works in their original language. The syllabus will include Beowulf, the Lais of Marie de France, The Book of Beasts, Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, and selections from Chaucer's Canterbury Tales and Malory's Morte D'Arthur.

course.course_description: (Lecture). Occupying an uneasy place between the pre-industrial world of the eighteenth century and the rapidly urbanizing world of the Victorian period, the Romantic period represents a tipping point in the history of modernity. In this course, we will explore the literature of the British Romantic period as offering a set of diverse, complicated, and often contradictory answers to urgent questions. Among these are: What is the role of art in a multimedia age, or of the artist in a culture fascinated by celebrity? Does literature have something to teach us about justice and equality? Is it possible for human beings to develop sustainable ways of life, or are we doomed to destroy the planet and ourselves? Readings include poems by Blake, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Shelley, Keats, Barbauld, Clare, and Landon; one major work of non-fiction prose, Thomas De Quincey's Confessions of an English Opium-Eater; and two novels, Jane Austen's Persuasion and Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.

This course is a study of romantic poetry and poetics but does not approach its subject from the belated perspective of the Victorians or the Moderns. Instead, the famous Romantics of the late 18th and early 19th centuries are viewed proleptically, from the vantage point of early and mid 18th-century poets who established the modern criteria and generated the forms and ideas later ingeniously personalized by the poets we customarily refer to as the Romantics. Indeed, though we shall spend the concluding half of our study with Wordsworth, Coleridge, Shelley, and Keats, our study begins with the neoclassical romanticism of Pope, Thomson, Akenside, the Wartons, Gray, and Goldsmith. As such, our reading entails a study of lyric trends bridging 18th - and 19th-century verse and of related discourses in aesthetic psychology, moral philosophy, experimental religion, natural description, and affective criticism. We shall attend closely to rhetorical and prosodic elements, with a view to characteristic genres (ode, epistle, georgic, epitaph), innovative hybrids and new forms (elegy, the "conversational" poem). Recommended and required readings in prose are of the period and include theoretical and critical writings by our poets.

We will pay special attention to Alfred Tennyson and Robert Browning, and their great poetic innovation, the dramatic monologue. We will also be concentrating on poems by Elizabeth Barrett Browning, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Christina Rossetti, Matthew Arnold, A. E. Housman, and Thomas Hardy.

(Seminar). Recent decades have witnessed a flood of life writing about illness and disability. This development represents a significant change, as autobiography has historically been reserved for the most accomplished and able-bodied among us. Our course will study the rise of illness and disability memoir, asking how it revises traditional autobiography as it attempts to carve out literary space for voices and bodies that have not historically been represented in public. We will consider how these new memoirs talk back to doctors and other health care professionals who medicalize the disabled body, as well as social environments that stigmatize and exclude the ill and disabled. We will also ask how race and gender inform stories of illness and disability, as well as investigating differences between physical and mental illness and/or disability. Each week we will read one memoir, paired with other writings meant to prompt discuss and critical examination. In addition to more traditional academic writing, students will also have opportunities to experiment with their own life writing.

course.course_name: From the Page to the Dance Stage: The Not So Secret Relationship between Dance and Literature
course.course_description: The curriculum of this course is designed to examine works of dance which have their origins in the written word. It is no secret that many works of literature have frequently been translated into movement pieces accompanied by music. A question to explore during this course is the reason why this has happened so often. Do audiences prefer to see stories staged with which they are already familiar? Why? Should we consider this choreography a complete act of creative orginality? What do we gain when a textual narrative is staged and set to music as a non-verbal art form? What do we lose? Which literary genres are most often transformed into dance pieces? Why are some texts privileged with dance interpretation(s) and others are not? Guests from the dance world speak about their various roles and participation in the act of creating ballets (specific to this course) which have their origin in literature. N.B. Both undergraduate and graduate students are invited to enroll. A background in dance is not a prequisite for the class. This class is cross-listed and approved in the Departments of English, Dance, and Comparative Literature.

course.course_name: Comic Theatre: From Shakespeare to the New York City Stage
course.course_description: Why do we still laugh at comic works from nearly 2500 years ago, comedies that have outlived their generations? An examination of the different forms of staged comedy throughout the centuries, beginning with foundational texts from Ancient Greece, especially Aristophanes. We consider how today's playwrights are still building on, and making reference to, primary works from the Western canon. Texts we will read range from Shakespeare, Jonson and Restoration comedies, to Wilde, Beckett, Hansberry, Tennessee Williams, Pinter, and Churchill. We will also cover contemporary work seen on the stages of New York, including short comic plays, stand up, and physical comedy. Attention will be given to comic characters, comic pretense, wit, humor, comedy of errors, comic gestures, comic archetypes, farce, cross-dressing, satiric comedy, comic relief, tragicomedy, romantic comedy, and theatre of the absurd. This course will be of special interest to serious students of comedy. When possible, class outings make use of current New York City productions.

course.course_description: (Lecture). The term "modernism" is unusual in that refers simultaneously to a style, an idea, and a period. Critics often argue about the beginning of the modernist period, some joining Virginia Woolf in dating it from "on or about 1910" (when "human character changed"), others pushing it back to 1890 or earlier. There is even more debate about when - or if - modernism ends. In the 1980s, critical theorists such as Fredric Jameson posited the existence of a decisive break between modernism and so-called postmodernism. More recently, scholars have become interested in the longevity and temporal unevenness of modernism as an aesthetic and social phenomenon. Inspired by such scholarship, this lecture class examines the evidence for a concept of "late modernism." We will examine late modernism in a number of guises: as an extension of modernist aesthetics into the late twentieth century; as an elegiac, negative, or inward turn within the modernist avant-garde; and as a symptom of an unevenly globalized modernity. Literary readings by the likes of W. H. Auden, Djuna Barnes, Samuel Beckett, Basil Bunting, T. S. Eliot, B. S. Johnson, Ann Quin, Jean Rhys, and Virginia Woolf. Critical and theoretical readings will come from figures such as T. W. Adorno, Clement Greenberg, Fredric Jameson, and Edward Said.

course.course_name: Topics in Comparative Literature: Useful Lies: The Predicament of Renaissance Fiction
course.course_description: This class explores a series of major works of European narrative fiction before the novel, beginning with Boccaccio's 14th-century collection of novellae, the Decameron, and ending with Aphra Behn's late 17th-century proto-novel, Oroonoko. While each book on the syllabus exemplifies a different genre from the period, all of the texts take on in some fundamental way the topic of fiction itself: its definition, its relationship to other types of communication, and its possible roles in the world. We also read a few secondary works to help us begin exploring the extent to which some of the most important 20th-century theories of narrative fiction, composed largely to make sense of "the novel," can help illuminate these pre-novelistic literary forms. Other authors include Rabelais, George Gascoigne, Thomas More, Philip Sidney, Cervantes, Edmund Spenser, and H.J.C. von Grimmelshausen. The writing for the class consists of two short critical papers (plus rewrites), the first on an assigned topics, the second on a topic students develop themselves. course.course_name: The Comparative European Novel: The Female Adventure Story
course.course_description: This course in the bourgeois realist novel of the latter half of the nineteenth century explores a spectrum of female subjectivities from multiple class and historical perspectives. Remnants of the ancien rï¿½gime linger; yet in Tess, Hardy chose a daughter of the rural poor as his protagonist; meanwhile bourgeois housewives are taking poison or throwing themselves in front of an oncoming train. Patterns of bourgeois consumption as well as productionï¿½or lack thereof, as the case may beï¿½will be of recurring interest. Of additional concern will be the novelsï¿½ representations of history, whether the Napoleonic Wars in the foreground or the July Monarchy in the background, and comparatively, the contrasts the novels present and tensions they illustrate between the cosmopolitan city and the provinces. One of our manifest concerns in each of these novels will be the way in which each female subject is defined and dramatized in relationship to her social milieu, whether domestic or societal or both. Finally, we will dedicate substantial discussion to the construction of these ï¿½loose baggy monsters,ï¿½ as Henry James referred to large nineteenth-century novels. In other words, we will study these novels as works of a particular genre that reached its apotheosis during the bourgeois era; but we will conduct our aesthetic inquiry predominantly through the criticism of the post bourgeois realist novelist Virginia Woolf, especially her Common Reader essays. We will read all non-English language novels in translation; however, if there is a majority among us with working knowledge of French, we will look at brief sections in the original in order to analyze what Flaubert accomplishes at the level of language.

course.course_name: Topics in Comparative Literature: Transatlantic Selves
course.course_description: Autobiography is an extraordinarily popular form of writing today, from tell-all memoirs to Twitter updates.  This course looks back to the beginning of our modern-day fascination with the self, reading autobiographical writings from 17th-century England and colonial America.  We will examine how John Bunyan, Margaret Cavendish, Benjamin Fanklin, and other authors use their writings both to explore ideas of selfhood and to situate those selves in the history and politics of their time.  Over six weeks, we will read a variety of works, including travel writing, diaries, spiritual autobiographies, memoirs of war and exile, and a colonial captivity narrative.

Eliot, Wallace Stevens, Gertrude Stein, H.D., Ezra pound, Mina Loy, Kurt Schwitters, W.C. Williams, Charles Olson, John Cage, and Frank O'Hara.

course.course_name: Comic Books and Graphic Novels as Literature
course.course_description: In 1950, eminent social theorist C.L.R. James declared that it is in the "serious study" of popular comic strips like Dick Tracy and Gasoline Alley that "you find the clearest ideological expression of the American people and a great window into the future of America and the modern world." This course will take a prolonged look through this ‘great window' to trace the history of comics and graphic novels in the United States. Focusing on major representative texts that define and redefine the genre, we will learn how to approach comics as a distinct literary and visual form, while familiarizing ourselves with the critical vocabulary of "sequential art." By examining the graphic novel with an eye toward the literary, the course will examine the ways it deploys conventional literary forms such as allegory, epic, character, setting, and extended metaphor. We will consider how comics resist, represent, and entrench dominant cultural ideologies about power, myth, heroism, humor, adolescence, gender, sexuality, family, poverty, religion, censorship, and the immigrant experience. The course will provide students with the critical tools to examine this key vehicle of contemporary creative expression. Readings will include seminal works by Bechdel, Burns, Eisner, Miller, Moore, Crumb, Pekar, Spiegelman, Ware, and others. In addition, we will read selections from texts on graphic narrative theory and comics history, beginning with Scott McCloud's Understanding Comics. A field trip will also take us to Columbia's own Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

In the instantaneity of its horror and in its far-flung repercussions, 9/11 is unpossessable. It is a limit event that shatters the symbolic resources of the culture and defeats the normal processes of meaning-making and semiosis. No stylistic device, no trick of the imagination, no amount of ingenuity or inventiveness can even begin to render the 'primal terror' of people burning alive, in desperation jumping from the towers hand in hand, or being crushed to death. And yet, as Don DeLillo contends, "living language is not diminished." Even something as indescribable as what happened on that sunny Tuesday morning cannot stay out of the reach of symbol and metaphor. In this course we will study how artists, philosophers, architects, film makers, journalists and especially fiction writers have found ways of dealing with what in essence is an unrepresentable reality. We will look at the various methods that have been used to describe or evoke the destruction of the Twin Towers and will discuss questions relating to narrative strategy and stylistic "appropriateness." Attention will be paid to topics such as: the history of the World Trade Center, 9/11 and trauma, 9/11 and irony, the political uses and abuses of the events. We will study how fictional texts reflect the subtle changes that, as a result of the terrorist attacks, have taken place in the culture of the U.S. and other countries. And, finally, we will deal with fictional texts in which the nature and the causes of terrorism are examined. Readings include Art Spiegelman's In the Shadow of No Towers, Jonathan Safran Foer's Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close, Anita Shreve's A Wedding in December and John Updike's Terrorist.

(Lecture). We can't talk about human rights without talking about the forms in which we talk about human rights. This course will study the convergences of the thematics, philosophies, politics, practices, and formal properties of literature and human rights. In particular, it will examine how literary questions of narrative shape (and are shaped by) human rights concerns; how do the forms of stories enable and respond to forms of thought, forms of commitment, forms of being, forms of justice, and forms of violation? How does narrative help us to imagine an international order based on human dignity, rights, and equality? We will read classic literary texts and contemporary writing (both literary and non-literary) and view a number of films and other multimedia projects to think about the relationships between story forms and human rights problematics and practices. Likely literary authors: Roberto Bolaño, Miguel de Cervantes, Assia Djebar, Ariel Dorfman, Slavenka Drakulic, Nuruddin Farah, Janette Turner Hospital, Franz Kafka, Sahar Kalifeh, Sindiwe Magona, Maniza Naqvi, Michael Ondaatje, Alicia Partnoy, Ousmane Sembène, Mark Twain . . . . We will also read theoretical and historical pieces by authors such as Agamben, An-Na'im, Appiah, Arendt, Balibar, Bloch, Chakrabarty, Derrida, Douzinas, Habermas, Harlow, Ignatieff, Laclau and Mouffe, Levinas, Lyotard, Marx, Mutua, Nussbaum, Rorty, Said, Scarry, Soyinka, Spivak, Williams.

course.course_description: (Lecture). This course is a survey of American literatures and cultures ranging from the colonial era to the Age of Revolution. Although many of the texts on the syllabus were written in colonies that would eventually become part of the United States, the course itself is not designed to be a literary history of the U.S. Instead, we will put pressure on terms like "American" and "Literary" as we inquire into the theological, political, scientific, and literary issues that framed colonial experiences. Our goal will be to explore the various modes through which colonial encounters were described by foregrounding the local, regional, and Atlantic contexts of the material we read. In particular, we will consider the multiple trajectories of Early American literary history by examining subjects like Exploration and Captivity, Puritan Theology, Antinomianism, the Enlightenment, the Caribbean, Slavery and Emancipation, and Revolution. Our investigations will push us to test the conceptual limits of these categories as we trace their place in emerging discourses of nation. Authors may include: William Bradford, John Winthrop, Anne Bradstreet, Mary Rowlandson, Benjamin Franklin, William Earle, Olaudah Equiano, Phillis Wheatley, Charles Brockden Brown, and Mary Prince. This course satisfies the American, the prose fiction / narrative, and the pre-1800 period requirements for the major.

course.course_description: (Lecture). The class will be guided by the premise that the writings of Poe and Melville not only reflect mid-19th century modernity but are also generated by it. To support this claim we will look closely into their experimentation with narrative structure and ask whether the absence of clearly delineated characters in their stories and novellas is related to the emergence of urban crowds, the intensified feeling of anonymity in the lives of New York city dwellers, and practices of dehumanization employed in New York and Philadelphia prisons, alm houses, asylums and hospitals. We will follow how their obsession with a violence that "undoes" persons might be understood as a critique of slavery or incarceration, and inquire into the theories of life that both authors drew from contemporary sciences such as biology and medicine, in order to formulate their critique of capital punishment, as well as other types of corporal punishment used on plantations and in prisons. Additionally, we will reconstruct how their insistence on non-taxonomical thinking derived from their interest in pseudo-sciences such as natural magic, mesmerism or phrenology, and investigate the political and ethical consequences of such thinking. We will pay special attention to their interest in the occult and supernatural with a view to understanding that it was in those realms that they sought to reveal how the secular means of control of the persons function. And finally, we will discuss how categorical divides between human and non-human, so prominent in their work, function as a form of resistance to the extermination of animal species enacted by colonization and industrialization, as well as a critique of the suffering inflicted on animals by the aestheticization of modern life (zoological gardens, city parks, circuses, etc.). To reconstruct the multilayered relations their writing maintained with its historical context we will read texts by Jacob Bigelow, Sir David Brewster, Charles Darwin, Orville Dewey, Charles Dickens, William Goodell, and Justice Lemuel Shaw. However, the major emphasis of the class will be on close readings of Melville's works (Moby Dick (1851); Israel Potter (1855); The Piazza Tales (1856), The Confidence Man (1857); Battle Pieces and Aspects of War (1866); Clarel: A Poem and A Pilgrimage (1876); Billy Budd, Sailor (1924)) and Poe's poetry, prose and journalism.

course.course_description: (Lecture). The very name of the modernist movement suggests its concern with the new, the current, and the up-to-date. So too did modernism in the United States draw much of its dynamic energy from its pathbreaking national moment, one of American jazz, skyscrapers, movies, airplanes, immigration waves, and economic booms. But the modern cannot exist but in opposition to the old, and so in this course we will study formally experimental works whose freshness grows out of a deep sense of the past. How does the modern engage with the anti-modern, and to what end? In addition to literature, we will discuss historiographical methods, nostalgia, primitivism, folk culture, memory and the subconscious, Old Europe and expatriation, and legacies of slavery and the Civil War. Authors might include DuBois, Fitzgerald, Eliot, O'Neill, Toomer, Hemingway, Cather, Pound, H.D., Williams, Faulkner, Hurston, and Dos Passos. There will be papers, an exam, and opportunities for in-class discussion.

course.course_description: A course in the fiction of F. Scott Fitzgerald and Ernest Hemingway that focuses on the connection between close reading and cultural analysis. These writers offer a comparison and contrast that is essential to the understanding of American literary consciousness in the first half of the 20th century.

The cultural and economic transformation of America in this period is imaginatively recorded in the evolution of the American novel, which shows how turbulent social and racial pressures recast established ideas of the self, the family, and society. The period includes a wide range of novelistic approaches and categories, including naturalism, realism, and regionalism. Themes include the emergence of a new, national culture, superceding both local culture and European standards; the decline of agrarian culture, immigration, and the emergence of the new city; and the legacy of slavery. Our emphasis is on the close reading, analysis, and discussion of major novels, with the aim of seeing how they relate to one another and trace major developments. Henry James, Kate Chopin, Stephen Crane, Herman Melville, Mark Twain, James Weldon Johnson, Willa Cather, Edith Wharton, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and Zora Neale Hurston.

From a 21st Century point of view, two of the most venerable American authors, Nathaniel Hawthorne and Herman Melville, appear to be very strange literary specimens. Nobody talks or writes the way they did anymore-it could be argued that, apart from the characters in their books, nobody ever did. Both are far more than dusty monuments, however. Their thorny, sometimes baroque language holds the key, not only to the bleaker passages of America's past, but to their authors' tormented souls. Linked by ties of mutual admiration, friendship, time, and geography, the two were also kindred spirits in their obsession with the dark side of the American psyche. This course will begin with a look at Hawthorne's The Custom House, that nearly uncategorizable chunk of prose found at the front of The Scarlett Letter. Several shorter tales will follow, as time allows. Moving on to Melville, students will examine two men of the sea as different from Moby Dick's Captain Ahab as they are from each other: the captain of the title in "Benito Cereno" and Captain Vere in Billy Budd. The goal of the course will be to explore the relevant historical themes of the works studied and to find in them illumination of the American present. Close reading will be the method, pursued in lecture and discussion. A variety of critical viewpoints will be opened up and student opinion welcomed, the more diverse the better.

The unprecedented arrival of immigrants into New York City at the turn of the century was a profoundly disruptive experience for both new arrivals and old Americans alike.  This course will consider how American literature responded to the challenges posed by the massive waves of immigrants to New York City between 1840 and 1924.  The readings will include novels by canonical figures like F. Scott Fitzgerald, Edith Wharton, Anzia Yezierska, and James Weldon Johnson.  We will develop our understanding of the fiction by readings in historical and cultural contexts: important voices in the era's national debate on immigration; Theodore Roosevelt, Horace Kallen and Abraham Cahan among others will be paired with contemporary news editorials, silent films and immigrant letters.  As the instructor is a registered New York City tour guide, the city itself will serve as a backdrop for framing questions about the connections between literature, history and American culture.

course.course_description: (Lecture). 3 points. This course surveys major works of American fiction, poetry, essays, literary and cultural criticism written since 1945. It will situate the analysis of literature against a historical backdrop that includes such key events as the Holocaust; the atomic bomb; the Beatniks; youth counterculture; the women's, peace, and Civil Rights movements; the Korean, Vietnam, and Gulf Wars; the energy crisis; globalization; the rise of the internet; and the War on Terror.  We will also consider major literary and artistic movements such as postmodernism, the Beats, confessional poetry, minimalism, the New Journalism, and historiographic metafiction. Lectures will emphasize literature in its cultural/ historical context, but will also attend to its formal/ aesthetic properties.

course.course_description: This course focuses on the poetry of T.S. Eliot and Ezra pound from its World War I era beginnings to the 1940s, the peak of their poetic fame and infamy. course.course_name: African American Literature: Contemporary African American Women's Novels
course.course_description: In this course, we will study novels by African American women writing from the post-Civil Rights Era to the present. The 1970 anthology The Black Woman, edited by Toni Cade Bambara, will serve as a jumping-off point for our study of how a number of contemporary authors imagine the category of "Black Woman," in all its complexity, in the late 20th century. Through studying the work of Bambara, Gayl Jones, Alice Walker, Paule Marshall, Ntozake Shange, Gloria Naylor, and Toni Morrison, we will examine literature in the decades of disillusionment following the Civil Rights Movement. Among the questions we will consider: How do we account for the increase in visibility and popularity of African American women's writing in the last three decades of the 20th century? How do these texts engage with the Black Power and Black Arts Movements? How are these texts in conversation with the predominantly white Women's Liberation Movement? How do these authors envision home, community, and the nation in their works? What role does African Diaspora play in these novels? How do these works define and exemplify nationalism, cultural or otherwise?

In this course, we will study the figure of the conjure woman in works by African Americans writing from the late nineteenth centure to the present.  We will study novels, short stories, and films by Charles Chestnutt, Jean Toomer, Rudolph Fisher, Ishmael Reed, Gloria Naylor, Kasi Lemmons, Erna Brodber, and Colson Whitehead, among others. There are no prerequisites for this course.

(Lecture). This course will focus on twentieth century poetry written by authors of African descent in Africa, the Caribbean, and the United States. The readings will allow us to cover some of the most significant poetry written during the major black literary movements of the century, including the Harlem Renaissance, Negritude, and the Black Arts movement. In particular, the course will be designed around a selection of books of poetry by black writers, such as Langston Hughes's Fine Clothes to the Jew, Aimé Césaire's Notebook of a Return to My Native Land, Audre Lorde's The Black Unicorn, and Rita Dove's Thomas and Beulah. We will thus spend a substantial amount of time reading each poet in depth, as well as discussing various strategies for constructing a book of poetry: thematic or chronological arrangements, extended formal structures (suites, series, or montages), historical poetry, attempts to imitate another medium (particularly black music) in writing, etc. We will use the readings to consider approaches to the theorization of a diasporic poetics, as well as to discuss the key issues including innovation, the vernacular, and political critique at stake in the tradition. Other authors covered may include Gwendolyn Brooks, Nicolás Guillén, Christopher Okigbo, Amiri Baraka, Edward Kamau Brathwaite, Nathaniel Mackey, and Harryette Mullen. Requirements: weekly response papers, a 5-7 pg. midterm paper and a 9-12 pg. final paper.

(Lecture). This course provides an introduction to Asian American literature since the mid-nineteenth century, with a focus on the most recent few decades. What does it mean to be Asian or partly Asian in America? Are there historical experiences, cultural expressions, or political positions that give Asian Americans a collective identity, as it is often assumed to be the case? How does the knowledge of their experiences and perspectives enrich our understandings of American culture and U.S.-Asian relations? We will examine these questions through the lens of literature, prose narratives and poetry in particular. In other words, we will discuss a selected group of literary works so as to uncover the ways in which some the most interesting minds among Asian Americans comment on the meanings of race, ethnicity, and culture, as well as their relations to other social issues, in both American and transnational contexts. Readings: Kingston, China Men; Yamamoto, Seventeen Syllables; Cha, Dictee; Hagedorn, Dogeaters; Ondaatje, Cat's Table; Yamashita, Tropic of Orange; Monique Truong, The Book of Salt; H.M. Naqvi, Home Boy; Greg Pak and David Henry Hwang, Robot Stories: And More Screen Plays.

course.course_description: In this course, we will read works by Kyd, Shakespeare, Middleton, Webster, and Ford, paying close attention to the possible performance dynamics of these plays. As a class we will ask how the revenge tragedies staged between 1586 and 1642 negotiate urgent post-reformation questions about the status of the visual in an iconophobic culture, about the soul, and about the relationship between the dead and the living.

(Seminar). In addition to some foundational essays of theory and criticism, the class will read closely with a theatrical point of view a number of major works by the three masters of early modern drama in the late-nineteenth and early-twentieth centuries. The course will focus on the stylistic innovations, thematic concerns, and performance possibilities created by each respective playwright. Particular emphasis will be to identify the writers' rebellions from melodrama and their unique worldviews produced by the distinctive, recurring and essential action of individual plays such as A Doll House, Ghosts, The Wild Duck, Hedda Gabler, The Master Builder, The Seagull, Three Sisters, The Cherry Orchard, Miss Julie, A Dream Play, The Ghost Sonata, and several more. Three short papers (5-7 pages), one on each playwright, regular attendance, and active class participation will be required. course.course_name: American Drama: The American Family Play
course.course_description: Intrafamilia conflict in drama has traditionally functioned as a vehicle for representing some other force: ancient Greek family plays, such as the Oresteia and Oedipus Rex, serve to illustrate divine control of human fate; and in Elizabethan drama, such as King Lear and Romeo and Juliet, family conflict represents a microcosm of the power struggles in the larger society. Even while transcending the limits of domestic realism, American drama of the 20th century often gives center stage to family conflict. For numerous reasons the quintessentially American play of the period can be characterized as a family drama. Playwrights whose texts will be studied in this context include Wilder, Miller, Hellman, Williams, Hansberry, Shepard, Marsha Norman, and others.

"What Americans have lacked in a sense of time they have tried to make up by an enlarged sense of space. Their thoughts tend not to run backward into a history they do not know but rather outward into a larger geographical theater of action, the theater not of the past but of the future." Richard HofstadterIf historian Richard Hofstadter is justified in his belief that Americans lack an ability to imagine the past, preferring instead to look towards limitless theaters of the future, how may we understand the project - undertaken throughout the last century by playwrights from Eugene O'Neill to Tony Kushner - to imagine the nation and its history on stage? Spurred by these questions, this course looks at dramatic texts that explore the intersection between performance, history and the American national imagination. In the first half of the course we examine early century plays centering on the idea of the nation as a family descended from "founding fathers" (Glaspell, Wilder and others) as well as post-World War Ii plays that begin to doubt the coherency and value of this inheritance (Miller, Williams, Albee). During the second half of the course we look at plays that revise or improvise on these earlier narratives in order to recuperate forgotten histories and imagine new ones (Wilson, Parks and others). While paying close attention to scene analysis and dramatic structure, we will consider broader conceptual questions including: How does America play itself on stage? How are its histories performed, reconstructed, documented and reinvented? How have playwrights experimented with dramatic form and genre in order to construct new historical narratives? How have some plays entered and become part of the histories they tell? In order to develop our understanding of these plays as performance texts that engage live events and actual spaces, three out-of-class field trips (one mandatory) will take us to Ellis Island, Coney Island and the Metropolitan Playhouse.

(Lecture). Survey of American drama from 1900-1960s. We will ask what makes American drama "American" and how American dramatists responded to European influences. We will also examine American drama's relationship to key cultural events and transformations of the early 20th century, such as the rise of mass culture; mechanization and alienation; labor unrest; race and racism; and Cold War paranoia. How has American identity been constructed and contested on stage? What are the broader social and political contexts of dramatic performance in the 20th century? How does drama relate to other media, such as film? Plays and films by D.W. Griffith, Harriet Beecher Stowe, Susan Glaspell, Eugene O'Neill, Elmer Rice, Sophie Treadwell, Langston Hughes, Clifford Odets, Arthur Miller, Tennessee Williams and Edward Albee.

course.course_name: Aspects of the Novel: The Victorian Novel a la Mode
course.course_description: This course will provide a survey of the Victorian novel with especial emphasis on genre and form. Novelistic modes considered include Autobiography, the City Novel, the Sensation Novel, the Social Problem Novel, the Social Novel and the Historical  Novel.   We will explore the development of the novel form and its sub-categories, querying the accuracy and usefulness of the distinctions these terms emphasize . Texts studied include Jane Eyre, Oliver Twist, The Woman in White, North and South, Barchester Towers and Romola, plus selected pieces  of non-fiction prose and poetry.

course.course_name: Studies in the Novel: Herman Melville & Thomas Pynchon
course.course_description: Proclaiming the appearance of the so-called Great American Novel is as fabled a literary pastime as the sighting of the white whale itself. This course aims to get beneath the surface of this rather trite proclamation in order to consider the interesting kinship of concerns that inform the work of two major American novelists, Herman Melville and Thomas Pynchon. Close reading and comparative study of their works, especially their epic novels Moby-Dick and Gravitys Rainbow, reveal a surprising correspondence between some of the formal and thematic preoccupations of these two authors. Students will be encouraged to think and pose questions about the form of the encyclopedic novel in the American literary tradition as well as many of the historical and cultural issues engaged by these texts. Of particular concern will be the continuities (and discontinuities) in how these two authors imagine the Puritan legacy and manifest destiny, or the relationship between Providential design, secular history, and narrative form. Issues of subjective agency and the conditioning structures of knowledge will also be central concerns in our reading of these texts. We will also reflect on some of the extra-textual questions raised by these novels: what it means, for example, to consider these novels as belonging to a specifically American literary tradition when their own thematic concerns are so explicitly international in orientation. In addition to the intensive reading of these two epic novels, we will also read a mystery novella by each author, Melvilles Benito Cereno and Pynchons The Crying of Lot 49. A course reader with supplementary readings will be provided.

course.course_description: (Lecture). Officially this is a "lecture" course, so everyone is welcome to come -- freshmen through seniors, as well as graduate students -- and there are no prerequisites whatsoever. But unlike many "lecture" courses, this course will have constant class discussion, so ATTENDANCE IS MANDATORY. Also, if you miss the first class, you cannot get into the course. This course applies knowledge of the English language and its history to issues of literature, law, and other things as well. There are no required books, but there will be plenty of handouts -- all of them supplied gratis. There will be about half a dozen graded written assignments, most of them only about two pages long, but at least one of them rather extensive; and there may be in-class exams. Class participation is a BIG part of the grade.

What historical, political, and social factors have given rise to the way we understand disability in contemporary American culture?  How have philosophers, policy makers, authors and artists framed the political and ethical debates surrounding the status of disability?  How have imaginative representations in literature, film, and the visual arts contributed to and/or challenged those understandings?  This course seeks to address these questions by considering a broad array of texts, including philosophical debates about morality and ethics, history, and literary, filmic, and visual representations.

The course focuses on the diction, imagery, narrative techniques, and principal thematic concerns of the English Bible, a literary masterpiece in its own right, and the single most important influence on English literature throughout the ages. Readings include complete works or substantial selections from major books of the Old and New Testaments and Apocrypha. Though our reading is in English, we consider the generic conventions and the social, cultural, and historical contexts in which biblical literature was produced. In addition to close literary study of individual biblical works from Genesis to Revelation, other topics to be considered include: the complexities of the construction of gender roles in and across various biblical texts; the problem of unity and diversity in a single book that is also an anthology of Near Eastern and Late Antique literary forms; the related problem of the canon of Scripture and its contested formation; the influential rabbinic mode of biblical interpretation known as midrash and contemporaneous Christian forms of biblical exegesis (parable, allegory, and typology); and the history and problematics of English Bible translation (with special attention to the literary and cultural landmarks of the Wycliffite Bible versions, c.1385-95, and the King James/Authorized Version, 1611). The influence of the Bible on English writers will occupy us throughout the course, and in their term papers students will have the option of exploring the relationship between a specific biblical text and a major English poem, play, or novel (e.g., Byron's Cain, Milton's Samson Agonistes, Robert Frost's Masque of Reason, etc.).

course.course_name: Hacking the Archive: The Digital Humanities Toolkit
course.course_description: (Seminar). How is the rapid development of global computer networks, digital media, and massive data archives changing the way we study history and culture? We now have access to unprecedentedly large and rich bodies of information generated from the digitization of older materials and the explosion of new content through social media. Machine learning and natural language processing make it possible to answer traditional research questions with greater rigor, and tackle new kinds of projects that would once have been deemed impracticable. At the same time, scholars now have many more ways to communicate with one another and the broader public, and it is becoming both easier - and more necessary - to collaborate across disciplines. Students in this course will begin by learning about some of the core concepts and practices of traditional literary, cultural, and historical analysis, and then consider how they might be transformed. They will explore tools and techniques that include data curation, named-entity extraction, part-of-speech tagging, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, machine and crowd-source translation, social and citation network analysis, and text visualization. The course will take shape as an intensive workshop, where we will gain and share methodological expertise, and begin to think big about digital archives, information architectures, live data, and large-scale textual corpora. The course is open to students at all levels of technical skill and with a variety of research interests. Expect to form groups led by graduate and faculty researchers, to work collaboratively, and to actively shape the trajectory of the course.

course.course_description: (Seminar). Reading selections from Lacan's Seminar XIV: The Logic of Phantasy 1966-7; Seminar XX: Encore: On Feminine Sexuality, the Limits of Love and Knowledge 1972-3; Seminar XXIV The unknown that knows the unconscious/or blunder takes wings at playing love/death game 1976-7 together with selected novels, short stories, and poems. Emphasis on Lacan's elaboration of the phantasy, the four discourses, jouissance, the formulas of sexuation, and his redefinition of our notions of the imagination, the body, language, and the function of the arts. Consideration of the relevance of his thought to literature, aesthetics, and culture.

The reading list for this course includes some of the most interesting and influential texts in twentieth-century Anglo-American literary criticism, interlarded with some bits of the French literary theory that influenced many American literary scholars in the closing decades of the last millennium. We will read the assigned texts closely and critically, both in order to understand what each one argues and to isolate and identify interpretive tactics that might be useful in our own critical work. Although we will touch regularly on intellectual history and the history of criticism, we will be especially attentive to questions of voice and argument; a significant portion of each class will be devoted to considering the choices each writer has made as they manifest themselves in style at the level of sentence, paragraph, chapter and book. ENGL G5001x Masters Seminar (Katherine Biers) W 10:10am-12:00pm. This course will explore some of the most important works of literary criticism, theory, and scholarship from the mid-twentieth century to the present. We will discuss different literary methodologies, including New Criticism, deconstruction, New Historicism, queer theory, affect theory, and more. But we will also turn the critical strategies of reading and interpretation back on the critics themselves. What choices do critics, theorists and scholars make in regard to voice, argument, evidence, and tone? What's the best way to use their work in our own work? Finally, we will discuss the larger question of what it means to interpret and teach English and American literature in the context of the research university. What gives literary study value? How do we (or should we?) define and justify the study of literature relative to the larger culture?

(Seminar). Chang Octagon Exhibition Room, Rare Book and Manuscript Library, 6th floor of Butler Library. This seminar will focus on theorizing the particular contours of radical knowledge production among African diasporic intellectuals in the twentieth century. We will read key works of African, Caribbean, and African American cultural and political movements, with particular attention to the relations between politics and poesis, and the ways that the exigencies of anticolonialism, civil rights, and Pan-Africanism have provoked methodological innovation in interdisciplinary work. We will focus especially on the implications of black radicalism for theories of the archive; to this end, we will not only read current scholarship on the issue, but also take advantage of recent acquisitions of the Rare Book and Manuscript Library at Columbia, including the papers of C.L.R. James, Hubert Harrison, Alexander Gumby, and Amiri Baraka. Participants will be expected to pursue original archival research in their work for the seminar. This is to say that the seminar will offer both an introduction to the methods and standards of archival practice (with an eye to the particular issues raised by African diasporic history), and a practicum in archival research using the holdings of RBML. Readings may include work by W.E.B. Du Bois, Hubert Harrison, C.L.R. James, Amiri Baraka, Ronald Hobbs, Grace Lee Boggs, Howard "Stretch" Johnson, and Alexander Gumby; and secondary scholarship by David Scott, Robert Hill, Arjun Appadurai, Stuart Hall, Michel Rolph-Trouillot, Cedric Robinson, Achille Mbembe, Carolyn Steedman, Saidiya Hartman, and Ann Stoler.

(Seminar). The aim of this course is to try to develop our own theories about the relation between poetry and erotic love, as each of these is understood and practiced. We will read a wide sweep of Western love poetry especially lyric but also narrative from the Song of Songs and Ovid to the present, though not necessarily in chronological order. These readings will be complemented by theoretical writings about love (by Plato, Freud, and Andreas Capellanus, among others) and by recent criticism of the major authors and genres we discuss.

(Seminar). “Liberty requires new definitions,” Carlyle declared in Past and Present (1843).  This seminar surveys a range of reflection on the nature of freedom within the world’s first industrial society, nineteenth-century Britain.   We’ll focus on the years between 1830 and 1870, exploring three related strands of engagement: democratic thought (including the position of women), political economy (particularly in debates linking “the factory question” and slavery), and an emergent ideal of “culture” as a mode of psychic autonomy.  Central texts include Carlyle,  Past and Present; E.B. Browning, “The Cry of the Children” and related lyrics; Gaskell, Mary Barton; Ruskin, “The Nature of Gothic”; William Morris, “Hopes and Fears for Art”; Charlotte Bronte, Jane Eyre; Mill, On Liberty; Arnold, Culture and Anarchy; Pater, “Wincklelmann”;  Wilde, “The Soul of Man Under Socialism” and “The Critic as Artist.” We’ll also glance back to formative texts from an earlier era: Smith, The Wealth of Nations; Burke, Reflections on the Revolution in France; Paine, The Rights of Man; Wollstonecraft, Vindication of the Rights of Woman.

course.course_name: Extraterritorial: Transnational Culture and the Politics of the State
course.course_description: (Seminar).  How do we square the redoubtable strength of the nation-state with the reality of our transnational culture? This course addresses this question by examining the past and present meanings of extraterritoriality, a concept that once provided the legal basis for European semi-colonialism in Asia and now underwrites a wide range of contemporary spaces, from Guantanamo Bay to nature reserves, immigration prisons to suburban "edgelands." Because it is founded on a paradox or constitutive tension (implying both the divisibility of national sovereignty and its perpetuation overseas) extraterritoriality is an important, if under-acknowledged, feature of the politics of transnational culture. We will explore this phenomenon via readings from contemporary fiction, visual arts, and theory. Our common goal will be to construct a tentative map of extraterritorial spaces, asking also whether such interzones and edgelands might not also create extra-temporal loopholes within the developmental time of modernity. Authors and artists studied include Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, J. G. Ballard, Janice Galloway, Melanie Friend, Kazuo Ishiguro, David Mitchell, and W.G. Sebald. Critics and theorists include Giorgio Agamben, Étienne Balibar, Judith Butler, Keller Easterling, Bonnie Honig, Susan Buck-Morss, Eyal Weizman, and others.

(Seminar). This course explores how the body, the senses, interiority, and materiality are constructed in ancient and medieval literary, philosophical, and religious texts and how they are connected with hermeneutic and cognitive practices. Texts from antiquity include Aristotle, Paul, Philo, Plotinus, Origen, and Augustine; texts from the Middle Ages include the Old English Body and Soul and The Ruin, Old English riddles, William of St. Thierry, Rudolf von Biberach, Guigo II, Marguerite d'Oingt, Hadewijch, Bernard of Clairvaux, and Victorine texts. The course will also look at how medieval readings of embodiment dialogue with, are commensurate to, or differ from readings of materiality and embodiment in Hegel, Marx, Merleau-Ponty, Lévinas, Derrida, Nancy, Lyotard, Negri, Agamben, and Butler. Given the tendency in the wave of phenomenology (Merleau-Ponty) to think of embodiment as a kind of radical inter-pentetration of world and body, what differences do we find in the revision to phenomenology evidenced by thinkers such as Lyotard, Derrida, and Nancy? How do the "materialities" in medieval mystical texts and their theological counterparts compare?

(Seminar).  The seminar examines the sociological, literary and historical work of W.E.B. Du Bois from The Philadelphia Negro(1899) to Dusk of Dawn(1940). In approaching the social surveys, novels and photographic essays of DuBois and his circle, the course will consider the relation between literature and sociology; the meaning of realism as it crosses the borders of art, social science, and literature; the formal affinities between visual and statistical graphics and the photographic index; the aesthetic and political work of journals like The Crisis and Survey; and the role of the novel in producing counter-histories of nation and empire. Du Bois's circle is drawn widely and includes: Jane Addams, Charles Chestnutt, Horace Clayton, St. Claire Drake, Theodore Dreiser, Paul Lawrence Dunbar, Lewis Hines, Frederick Hoffman, Pauline Hopkins, William Dean Howells, Frances Kellor, Jacob Riis, Booker T. Washington, and Ida B. Wells.
